pull.title: assumeutxo: change getchainstates RPC to return a list of chainstates
pull.body:
Current `getchainstates` RPC returns "normal" and "snapshot" fields which are not ideal because it requires new "normal" and "snapshot" terms to be defined, and the definitions are not really consistent with internal code. (In the RPC interface, the "snapshot" chainstate becomes the "normal" chainstate after it is validated, while in internal code there is no "normal chainstate" and the "snapshot chainstate" is still called that temporarily after it is validated).

The current `getchainstates` RPC is also awkward to use if you to want information about the most-work chainstate, because you have to look at the "snapshot" field if it exists, and otherwise fall back to the "normal" field.

Fix these issues by having `getchainstates` just return a flat list of chainstates ordered by work, and adding a new chainstate "validated" field alongside the existing "snapshot_blockhash" field so it is explicit if a chainstate was originally loaded from a snapshot, and whether the snapshot has been validated.

This change was motivated by comment thread in https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/28562#discussion_r1344154808

Concept ACK, would be good to have this in 26.0 so we don't change the RPC interface afterwards

issue.title: test: assumeutxo func test race fixes
issue.body:
Fixes https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/28585.

Fixes a few races within the assumeutxo tests:
- In general, `-stopatheight` can't be used with `connect_nodes` safely because the latter performs blocking assertions that are racy with the stopatheight triggering.
- Now that the snapshot chainstate is listed as `normal` after background validation, accept the final height from either chainstate.

events.body: Concept ACK, seems like a fine simplification!

issue.title: AssumeUTXO follow-ups
issue.body:
Addressing what I consider to be non- or not-too-controversial comments from #27596.

Let me know if I missed anything among the many comments that can be easily included here.

events.body: Rebased 3306714dae1e89ae95403da7bf6a7b28b45d9832 -> ff89dec6e65ac085ccfd000e147c801ca7a2138a ([`pr/getchain.1`](https://github.com/ryanofsky/bitcoin/commits/pr/getchain.1) -> [`pr/getchain.2`](https://github.com/ryanofsky/bitcoin/commits/pr/getchain.2), [compare](https://github.com/ryanofsky/bitcoin/compare/pr/getchain.1-rebase..pr/getchain.2)) due to conflict with #28589

Concept ACK

tACK ff89dec6e65ac085ccfd000e147c801ca7a2138a

Tested with a signet IBD, loading the snapshot and waiting for background sync to finish.

ACK ff89dec6e65ac085ccfd000e147c801ca7a2138a ([`jamesob/ackr/28590.1.ryanofsky.assumeutxo_change_getcha`](https://github.com/jamesob/bitcoin/tree/ackr/28590.1.ryanofsky.assumeutxo_change_getcha))

Good simplification, thanks. Built, ran tests locally.

Ah, just had a functional test fail while running in a loop. Investigating...
```

2023-10-05T12:58:59.655000Z TestFramework (INFO): Loading snapshot into second node from /tmp/bitcoin_func_test_smviasai/node0/regtest/utxos.dat
2023-10-05T12:58:59.658000Z TestFramework (INFO): Restarting node to stop at height 359
2023-10-05T12:59:00.111000Z TestFramework (INFO): Checking that blocks are segmented on disk

'''

Traceback (most recent call last):

AssertionError: Predicate ''''

''' not true after 60.0 seconds
```

Tangent, but @DrahtBot does not seem to pick up Sjors ACK with "Concept ACK" on the first line and "tACK" on the second line. I guess the ACK detector is overloaded
I'm ACK again once this change is made: https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/28590#discussion_r1347388519

Updated ff89dec6e65ac085ccfd000e147c801ca7a2138a -> 35f6d9073f282aec103e73089d133888d4dd7e62 ([`pr/getchain.2`](https://github.com/ryanofsky/bitcoin/commits/pr/getchain.2) -> [`pr/getchain.3`](https://github.com/ryanofsky/bitcoin/commits/pr/getchain.3), [compare](https://github.com/ryanofsky/bitcoin/compare/pr/getchain.2..pr/getchain.3)) fixing race condition in test

events.message:
assumeutxo: change getchainstates RPC to return a list of chainstates

Current getchainstates RPC returns "normal" and "snapshot" fields which are not
ideal because it requires new "normal" and "snapshot" terms to be defined, and
the definitions are not really consistent with internal code. (In the RPC
interface, the "snapshot" chainstate becomes the "normal" chainstate after it
is validated, while in internal code there is no "normal chainstate" and the
"snapshot chainstate" is still called that temporarily after it is validated).

The current getchainstatees RPC is also awkward to use if you to want
information about the most-work chainstate because you have to look at the
"snapshot" field if it exists, and otherwise fall back to the "normal" field.

Fix these issues by having getchainstates just return a flat list of
chainstates ordered by work, and adding new chainstate "validated" field
alongside the existing "snapshot_blockhash" so it is explicit if a chainstate
was originally loaded from a snapshot, and whether the snapshot has been
validated.

events.body: Updated 35f6d9073f282aec103e73089d133888d4dd7e62 -> a9ef702a877a964bac724a56e2c0b5bee4ea7586 ([`pr/getchain.3`](https://github.com/ryanofsky/bitcoin/commits/pr/getchain.3) -> [`pr/getchain.4`](https://github.com/ryanofsky/bitcoin/commits/pr/getchain.4), [compare](https://github.com/ryanofsky/bitcoin/compare/pr/getchain.3..pr/getchain.4)) taking James suggestion and making test a little stricter and more internally consistent

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -159,20 +162,12 @@ def no_sync():
         self.connect_nodes(0, 1)
 
         self.log.info(f"Ensuring snapshot chain syncs to tip. ({FINAL_HEIGHT})")
-
-        def check_for_final_height():
-            chainstates = n1.getchainstates()
-            # The background validation may have completed before we run our first
-            # check, so accept a final blockheight from either chainstate type.
-            cs = chainstates.get('snapshot') or chainstates.get('normal')
-            return cs['blocks'] == FINAL_HEIGHT
-
-        wait_until_helper(check_for_final_height)
+        wait_until_helper(lambda: n1.getchainstates()['chainstates'][-1]['blocks'] == FINAL_HEIGHT)
         self.sync_blocks(nodes=(n0, n1))
 
         self.log.info("Ensuring background validation completes")
         # N.B.: the `snapshot` key disappears once the background validation is complete.
-        wait_until_helper(lambda: not n1.getchainstates().get('snapshot'))
+        wait_until_helper(lambda: len(n1.getchainstates()['chainstates']) != 1)
comments.body: I'm not sure I follow this substitution... once background validation completes, `chainman.GetAll()` should (at least eventually) return only one chainstate: the fully-validated snapshot chainstate. Maybe `s/!=/==`?

comments.body: Funny, I think as-written this succeeds *most of the time* because the check is racily performed before validation actually completes, which essentially makes the check exit early.

comments.body:
re: https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/28590#discussion_r1347388519

> Funny, I think as-written this succeeds _most of the time_ because the check is racily performed before validation actually completes, which essentially makes the check exit early.

Right, this is the opposite of the condition you'd expect. ~Probably I just wrote the check one way, then inverted when it failed assuming I'd made a mistake. But either of these checks are racy, so it makes more sense to be direct and check the new "validated" field. Updated in new push~.

comments.body:
re: https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/28590#discussion_r1347392493

Actually thinking about it more, the change you suggested is not racy, and is a little better than just checking the "validated" field because it also ensures that the background chainstate disappears from the list after it is disabled. Also check you suggested is more consistent with the check done for the n2 node below on line 218
